repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
this is not part of the build system yet, so packager managers are supposed to install the file by themselves.

bash doesn't seem to provide shell completion, zsh embeds its own completion that is bundled with vim's.

Instead of copying zsh's completion, this generated one via https://github.com/RobSis/zsh-completion-generator

Setting as draft as I believe autocomplete generates:
```
_arguments:comparguments:327: invalid option definition: -o[N][Open N windows (default- one per file)]
_arguments:comparguments:327: invalid option definition: -o[N][Open N windows (default- one per file)]
```

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,35 @@
+#compdef nvim
+
+# zsh completions for 'nvim'
+# automatically generated with http://github.com/RobSis/zsh-completion-generator
+local arguments
+
+arguments=(
+  '--cmd[execute <cmd> before any config]'
+  '-l[\[args...\] Execute Lua <script> (with optional args)]'
+  '-S[source <session> after loading the first file]'
+  '-s[read Normal mode commands from <scriptin>]'

@@ -0,0 +1,35 @@
+#compdef nvim
+
+# zsh completions for 'nvim'
+# automatically generated with http://github.com/RobSis/zsh-completion-generator
+local arguments
+
+arguments=(
+  '--cmd[execute <cmd> before any config]'
+  '-l[\[args...\] Execute Lua <script> (with optional args)]'
+  '-S[source <session> after loading the first file]'
+  '-s[read Normal mode commands from <scriptin>]'
+  '-u[use this config file]'
+  '-d[diff mode]'
+  {-es,-Es}'[silent (batch) mode]'
+  {-h,--help}'[print this help message]'

@@ -0,0 +1,35 @@
+#compdef nvim
+
+# zsh completions for 'nvim'
+# automatically generated with http://github.com/RobSis/zsh-completion-generator
+local arguments
+
+arguments=(
+  '--cmd[execute <cmd> before any config]'
+  '-l[\[args...\] Execute Lua <script> (with optional args)]'
+  '-S[source <session> after loading the first file]'
+  '-s[read Normal mode commands from <scriptin>]'
+  '-u[use this config file]'
+  '-d[diff mode]'
+  {-es,-Es}'[silent (batch) mode]'
+  {-h,--help}'[print this help message]'
+  '-i[use this shada file]'
+  '-n[no swap file, use memory only]'
+  '-o+[open N windows (default: one per file)]'
+  '-O+[open N vertical windows (default: one per file)]'
+  '-p+[open N tab pages (default: one per file)]'
+  '-R[read-only (view) mode]'
+  {-v,--version}'[print version information]'

comment_data.body: would that work `'-s[read Normal mode commands from <scriptin>] file:_files'` (that's what I've added without testing. I wonder if the `"script` is mandatory ` `'-s[read Normal mode commands from <scriptin>]:script file:_files'` `
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,35 @@
+#compdef nvim
+
+# zsh completions for 'nvim'
+# automatically generated with http://github.com/RobSis/zsh-completion-generator
+local arguments
+
+arguments=(
+  '--cmd[execute <cmd> before any config]'
+  '-l[\[args...\] Execute Lua <script> (with optional args)]'
+  '-S[source <session> after loading the first file]'
+  '-s[read Normal mode commands from <scriptin>]'

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  '*--cmd[execute <cmd> before any config]:command'
  '*-c[Execute <cmd> after config and first file]:command'
  '-l[Execute Lua <script> (with optional args)]:script:_files -g "*.lua"'  # TODO: remaining args are passed to <script> and not opened by nvim for edit
  '-S[source <session> after loading the first file]::session:_files'
  '-s[read Normal mode commands from <scriptin>]:file:_files'
  '-u[use this config file]:config'
  '-d[diff mode]'
  {-es,-Es}'[silent (batch) mode]'
  '(- *)'{-h,--help}'[print this help message]'
  '-i[use this shada file]:shada:_files -g "*.shada"'
  '-n[no swap file, use memory only]'
  '-o-[open N windows (default: one per file)]::N'
  '-O-[open N vertical windows (default: one per file)]::N'
  '-p-[open N tab pages (default: one per file)]::N'
  '-R[read-only (view) mode]'
  '(- *)'{-v,--version}'[print version information]'
  '-V[verbose \[level\]\[file\]]'
  '(- *)--api-info[write msgpack-encoded API metadata to stdout]'
  '--clean["Factory defaults" (skip user config and plugins, shada)]'
  '--embed[use stdin/stdout as a msgpack-rpc channel]'
  '--headless[dont start a user interface]'
  '--listen[serve RPC API from this address]:address'
  '--remote[\[-subcommand\] Execute commands remotely on a server]'
  '--server[connect to this Nvim server]:address'
  '--startuptime[write startup timing messages to <file>]:file:_files'
```

comment_data.body:
It's hard to spot changes this way. Maybe we can merge a first version and then you update it afterwards ? 
I had hoped we could keep the completion in sync with manpage via https://github.com/RobSis/zsh-completion-generator but I guess it's a pipedream.

comment_data.body:
IIUC `nvim -l a.lua foo` behaves like `lua a.lua foo`, so `-l` should not complete files.

And `--remote-subcommand`s are listed in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/b750dee0a51917b236bdfe6fe6297fe5854f73a5/runtime/doc/remote.txt#L23-L58.

comment_data.body:
```zsh
'-s[read Normal mode commands from <scriptin>]:file:_files'
#                                             ^
```
See the below patch.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,35 @@
+#compdef nvim
+
+# zsh completions for 'nvim'
+# automatically generated with http://github.com/RobSis/zsh-completion-generator
+local arguments
+
+arguments=(
+  '--cmd[execute <cmd> before any config]'
+  '-l[\[args...\] Execute Lua <script> (with optional args)]'
+  '-S[source <session> after loading the first file]'
+  '-s[read Normal mode commands from <scriptin>]'

comment_regular_data.body: It's in contrib so doesn't really matter. But how often are nvim flags in the command line even used to warrant this? Anyway, that's a nitpick, have approved.

Could you try

```diff
- '-o[open N windows (default: one per file)]'
- '-O[open N vertical windows (default: one per file)]'
- '-p[open N tab pages (default: one per file)]'
+ '-o+[open N windows (default: one per file)]'
+ '-O+[open N vertical windows (default: one per file)]'
+ '-p+[open N tab pages (default: one per file)]'
```

If I'm not mistaken, this will indicate they require numeric arguments, which should prevent `_arguments` from misinterpreting them as standalone options.

@NotAShelf thanks for the tip, it worked.  I was able to confirm this worked after (re)learning a few tricks about zsh completion system. Basically to test, prepend the completion to FPATH (eg. `cp zsh-completion.zsh _nvim; FPATH=$PWD:$FPATH`, FPATH is tied to fpath and vice-versa). You might have to `compinit -D` to skip the completion cache .zcompdump. I put some random comments in the completion file and they appeared in completion.

So now depending on the distribs and order in fpath, it's not sure if zsh default completion will prevail or this one. And it might be less complete than zsh's but at least it's tied to neovim now and not zsh, we can improve and cherry-pick from zsh's if that's necessary later.
I would like to mention it in news.txt for package managers to install it. Is news.txt autogenerated/where should I put the announcement ?

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and agility. Consider helping sustain Neovim development!
repo.name: neovim

labels.description: building and installing Neovim using the provided scripts
labels.name: build

title: build(contrib): add zsh completion
